Responsible Iowa businesses already accommodate pregnant workers. Now let's make sure more businesses do.
  

Dear ##first_name[Supporter]##,

This legislative session we'll be pushing hard once again for the Pregnant Workers' Rights Act. This bill simply restores the previous, straightforward standard that required businesses merely to provide "reasonable accommodation" for a pregnant worker, as long as it doesn't create an "undue burden" for that business.

This can include things like allowing for restrictions on lifting certain weights, more frequent rest periods, or providing a stool for the worker to sit on.

Contact your legislator today and urge them to support the Iowa Pregnant Worker's Rights Act.

Most businesses do this anyway – it's good for employees and it's good for businesses. But after a 2015 change in the way Iowa law was interpreted, many pregnant workers were left vulnerable. This legislation is needed to nudge less-responsible businesses to provide some very basic, simple accommodations for pregnant women, like additional bathroom breaks or additional time for doctor's appointments.

This bill has bi-partisan support, but the pregnant workers of Iowa also need you to call or email your legislator before the session begins in January and urge them to support this legislation.

Find your legislator's contact information on The Iowa Legislature website.

We hear again and again that just a dozen constituents contacting their state legislator has an impact. Call your legislator before the session begins on Monday, January 8!

Sincerely,

Mark Stringer
Executive Director
ACLU of Iowa
